conclusion: Determine the magnitude of the Ampere force received by the ν-shaped current-carrying wire.
Magnetic flux Φ through a current-carrying wire is given by Φ = B ⋅ A ⋅ sin(θ).
B is the magnetic induction intensity, A is the area of the wire, θ is the angle between the magnetic field and the normal to the area.
Area A of the ν-shaped current-carrying wire can be calculated using the formula for the area of a triangle: A = 1/2 ⋅ base ⋅ height.
ν-shaped current-carrying wire has equal side lengths and an included angle of 60°.
Assume base and height are equal, therefore A = 1/2 ⋅ 2l ⋅ 2l = 2l².
Substitute values into the magnetic flux formula: Φ = B ⋅ 2l² ⋅ sin(60°).
Ampere force F on a current-carrying wire is given by F = μ₀ I ⋅ A ⋅ sin(θ).
μ₀ is the permeability of free space, I is the current, A is the area of the wire, θ is the angle between the magnetic field and the normal to the area.
Substitute values: F = μ₀ I ⋅ 2l² ⋅ √3/2 = √3 μ₀ I l².
Magnitude of the Ampere force received by the ν-shaped current-carrying wire is √3 μ₀ I l².
